pageData.text: Systematics is the study of evolutionary relationships based on shared <button class='glossary-text'>derived</button> <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button>. Using a variety of molluscan shells, students will describe characters, create a data matrix, and evaluate evolutionary trees.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Printed cladogram template or blank white paper

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText: Activity: 1 - 45 minutes

text: Explain the relationship between <button class='glossary-text'>taxonomy</button> and cladistics.
Define <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button> and list <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button>.
Construct a data matrix based on morphological characters.
Distinguish between monophyletic, polyphyletic, and <button class='glossary-text'>paraphyletic groups</button>.
Calculate the tree length and <button class='glossary-text'>consistency index</button> and use these parameters to identify the most parsimonious cladogram.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Cladistics is a useful tool for organizing groups of living things and understanding the evolutionary relationship between different organisms. While cladistics is widely used by - and was originally developed for - biologists, this relationship methodology can also be used in other fields. Linguists in particular find cladistics a helpful tool in mapping out the relationships between languages. Because languages can also be analyzed by <button class='glossary-text'>character state</button> changes, such as word order and tense usage, the same principles of cladistics can be applied to groups of languages. These groupings can help linguists and anthropologists understand both how and why languages change over time and the patterns of human migration before written history.  Much of this modelling is done with high-powered computers, which can analyze large data sets from many different languages and detect patterns that humans may take for granted or not initially notice. And, just like biologists use fossil evidence to understand cladistic groups, linguists can add information from dead and obscure languages to find connections which might have originally been missed.

pageData.desc: The word hello in many different languages.
pageData.altText: The word hello in many different languages.

pageData.subTitle: Classification Systems
pageData.text: To classify organisms, humans tend to group species according to similar characteristics. In 1735, Carl Linnaeus created a naming and classification system (<button class='glossary-text'>taxonomy</button>), which subsequently served as the basis for biological classification. Linnaeus proposed several ranks (<button class='glossary-text'>taxa</button>) that are still used today, namely, kingdom, class, order, family, genus, and species. In particular, the binomial system of a genus name followed by a species name is the standard for most organisms.

However, since Linnaeus’s time, a separate classification system has evolved. Cladistics—also called phylogenetics—seeks to organize organisms based on evolutionary relationships. Historically, scientists viewed morphological (physical) similarities as indicators of relatedness. They would look for homologous structures, i.e., structures that organisms have in common; presumably, these structures were inherited from a common ancestor. These traits, or <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button>, are called shared <button class='glossary-text'>derived</button> characteristics. For each trait, a set of <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button> is defined. For example, the character might be number of petals on a flower and the character state might be “multiples of 4” or “multiples of 3.” Alternatively, the character could be body covering and the corresponding character state might be “hair,” “feathers,” or “scales.” Other characters are defined by their presence or absence, such as the presence or absence of gills.

pageData.subTitle: Evolutionary Trees
pageData.text: By charting the characters and character states for a group of organisms, a hypothesis of the evolutionary relationships between these organisms can be constructed. This hypothesis is called a . A resembles a family tree, with all the current living species in the youngest generation. Related organisms and their common ancestor are organized into , which can be graphically depicted using a cladogram (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Example of a slanted cladogram with 8 taxa
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Example of a slanted cladogram with 8 taxa

pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>clade</button> is a monophyletic group that comprises a group of a common ancestor and all its descendants. In <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>taxa</button> A and B form a clade joined at node a; this node represents the most recent common ancestor of both taxa. Taxa A, B, and C also form a clade joined at node b, and this node represents the most recent common ancestor of all three taxa.

Trees can be drawn in a variety of ways. Figure 2 represents exactly the same information as in Figure 1. Note that although the orders of taxa F and G have been changed, the interpretation of the tables remains the same. Taxa D and E are most closely related to each other, and their next closest relatives are in the clade comprising taxa A, B, and C; this is because all share a common ancestor, namely, c. In other words, closeness of relationship is determined by a common ancestor, and not by the order in which the taxa are listed.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: An example of a cladogram presenting the same 8 taxa and their relationships as presented in Figure 1; in this image, the clades are boxy branches rather than slanted ones
pageData.altText: Figure 2: An example of a cladogram presenting the same 8 taxa and their relationships as presented in Figure 1; in this image, the clades are boxy branches rather than slanted ones

pageData.text: The following groups are frequently referred to by biologists based on shared common characteristics; however, they are phylogenetically invalid. Prokaryotes: Unicellular organisms lacking a nucleus are referred to as Prokaryotes. This group contains Bacteria and Archaea, and it is paraphyletic because Archaea and Eukarya (organisms having membrane-bound organelles including a nucleus) share a common ancestor that does not include Bacteria.Dicots: Botanists designate flowering plants as monocots and dicots based on a number of features. Monocots have a single embryonic leaf, major leaf veins running parallel to each other, and scattered vascular bundles in their stems. Dicots have two embryonic leaves, a network of veins, and stem vascular bundles arranged in a ring. Monocots arose from a dicot ancestor, and therefore they would need to be included to make dicots a monophyletic group.

pageData.question: Which statement is true about the figures below?

options.text: Figure 2 displays the same evolutionary relationships as in Figure 1.
Figure 2 has a different common ancestor for Taxa C and D than Figure 1.
Figure 2 has a different common ancestor for Taxa A and B than Figure 1.
Figure 2 has a different common ancestor for Taxa C and B than Figure 1.
Figure 2 has a different common ancestor for Taxa A and D than Figure 1.

image.desc: Figure 1: A phylogenetic tree of 8 taxa with slanted branches. The branch for taxon A extends up and to the left. The other 7 taxa are at the ends of branches extending up and to the right from this left-most branch. The taxa of these branches, in order from closest to furthest from taxon A, are B, C, E – from which branch extends a small branch with taxon D, G – from which branch extends a small branch with taxon F, and H. At the node where taxa A and B split is a lowercase A. At the node where taxon C and the branch leading to taxa A and split is a lowercase B.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: By charting the characters and character states for a group of organisms, a hypothesis of the evolutionary relationships between these organisms can be constructed. This hypothesis is called a phylogeny. A cladogram resembles a family tree, with all the current living species in the youngest generation. Related organisms and their common ancestor are organized into clades, which can be graphically depicted using a cladogram.  A clade is a monophyletic group that comprises a group of a common ancestor and all its descendants. In Figure 2, taxa A and B form a clade joined at node a; this node represents the most recent common ancestor of both taxa. Taxa A, B, and C also form a clade joined at node b, and this node represents the most recent common ancestor of all three taxa.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: By charting the characters and character states for a group of organisms, a hypothesis of the evolutionary relationships between these organisms can be constructed. This hypothesis is called a phylogeny. A cladogram resembles a family tree, with all the current living species in the youngest generation. Related organisms and their common ancestor are organized into clades, which can be graphically depicted using a cladogram.  A clade is a monophyletic group that comprises a group of a common ancestor and all its descendants. In Figure 2, taxa A and B form a clade joined at node a; this node represents the most recent common ancestor of both taxa. Taxa A, B, and C also form a clade joined at node b, and this node represents the most recent common ancestor of all three taxa.

pageData.text: Traditional Linnaean groups frequently work within the context of phylogenetic classification, even if the rankings (kingdom, class, order, etc.) are artificial; however, in other cases, the Linnaean groups fail to reflect the evolutionary history. One of the best examples of this is the traditional Linnaean grouping of Aves (birds) and Reptilia (reptiles). The Linnaean group Reptilia includes lizards, turtles, snakes, and crocodiles.

Crocodiles share a more recent common ancestor with birds than they do with snakes, lizards, or turtles. Hence, the group Reptilia is considered to be a <button class='glossary-text'>paraphyletic group</button> because it contains a group and its common ancestor but excludes one or more descendant groups (in this case birds).

There are several difficulties associated with selecting <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button> to use in phylogenetic analysis. It is often difficult to determine whether specific structures are homologous. For example, birds and bats have wings, but they may not share a common, winged ancestor. In fact, genetic analysis suggests that wings evolved separately in birds and bats. Therefore, wings in birds and bats are analogous structures (similar in function or form, but not in origin) and not homologous structures (similar in origin). Inadvertently grouping organisms using analogous structures results in <button class='glossary-text'>polyphyletic groups</button> (groups <button class='glossary-text'>derived</button> from more than one ancestor). For many years, biologists considered birds to be more closely related to mammals than to reptiles because they are both endothermic. Warm-bloodedness most likely arose separately in mammals and birds, making “endotherms” a polyphyletic group.

A <button class='glossary-text'>phylogeny</button> is a prediction of an evolutionary relationship, and therefore, only evolutionarily relevant characters should be used. In other words, the characters used for the phylogeny should be inheritable. Morphological characteristics, even inheritable ones, are frequently influenced by the environment. Human height is a good example. An individual’s height is determined in part by genetics; however, nutrition and other environmental factors also influence height. Using characters that display this type of variation can be problematic for phylogenetic analyses because the contributions of heredity and the surrounding environment cannot be isolated.

One solution to the problem of determining which characteristics are inheritable is to go straight to the source of heredity itself and use DNA sequences as characters for phylogenetic analyses. The increasing ease with which genes can be sequenced makes this an attractive option; however, even this method can be problematic. DNA sequences comprise a series of bases—adenine, cytosine, guanine, and thymine.

There are only five states for each <button class='glossary-text'>character</button> (one of the four bases, or the absence of a base in the event of a sequence deletion); therefore, it is very easy for a state to change from one base to another and back again without being detected. Fortunately, the sheer number of characters available in a DNA sequence helps to minimize the impact of these types of problems.

The selection of genetic loci for analysis can depend greatly on the expected distance of the relationships. A genetic locus is a location in the <button class='glossary-text'>genome</button>, the complete set of DNA in an organism. Some genetic loci code for proteins; these loci are called genes. Some genes are crucial for metabolism and are virtually identical even in distantly related organisms. These genes are so critical for survival that they are under intense selection pressure to remain unchanged. Other loci control regions that determine which genes are turned into proteins, and how quickly these genes are transcribed into messenger RNA, or mRNA, and subsequently translated into proteins. These loci tend to be well-conserved regions. Other regions of the genome change rapidly. For example, introns, which are regions of non-coding DNA that are removed from mRNA before translation, can change so rapidly that they are able to distinguish between two individual populations within a single species. Genes used in phylogenetic analysis must have sufficient variation to show differences but not so much variation that the characters are likely to have changed back and forth many times.

After characters have been selected, there are several methods of constructing a phylogenetic tree. These methods can be classified into two main groups—cladistic and .Phenetic methods rely on a series of distance calculations, based on the number of differences between pairs of . These calculations are simple and can be performed mentally, using a small data set. No assumptions about relationships are made prior to analysis and all characters are weighted equally. evaluate phylogenetic trees based on the principle of , i.e., that the best tree is the one with the fewest number of changes. This type of analysis requires an , i.e., a taxon that is known to be outside or to the group of taxa being examined. Taxa are grouped according to their changes from the outgroup. Ideally, all possible tree arrangements are tested; however, historically, this has been very difficult. A simple tree, containing only five organisms and having the simplest construction with only four internal nodes, would have 105 possible trees. Complex trees, such as the ones presented in and , could have as many as 4,336 possible permutations. As more taxa are added, the number of possible trees grows exponentially. Computer analyses are essential in identifying these possibilities. Even with the aid of computers, large data sets, with hundreds of characters and tens of taxa, require algorithms to narrow their search.

pageData.subTitle: Example
pageData.text: This example will apply cladistics methods to compare trees and determine the shortest tree among them. Table 1 lists five <button class='glossary-text'>taxa</button> with a variety of characteristics. In this example, taxon A has been designated as the <button class='glossary-text'>outgroup</button>.

A <button class='glossary-text'>character</button> matrix is created from potential characters. <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button> are defined and given a number. By definition, the character state of the outgroup is zero. Character traits shared with the outgroup are considered to be <button class='glossary-text'>ancestral</button> and those that differ from the outgroup are considered to be <button class='glossary-text'>derived</button>. This is not a distance matrix; therefore, it is not assumed that a character state of two is farther removed from zero than a character state of one.

tableData.hoverText:
A) A blue equilateral triangle with a single outline.
B) A blue rhombus with a single outline. 
C) A blue square with a double outline. 
D) An orange pentagon with a double outline. 
E) An orange pentagon with a single outline.

pageData.text: The first tree presented (Figure 3) has the simplest possible construction, with each node nested within the previous one. If the changes in <button class='glossary-text'>character state</button> are mapped onto the tree, the number of changes in each character state can be determined. The minimum number of changes is equal to the number of character states for that <button class='glossary-text'>character</button> minus one. In this example, color has two possible character states, dark blue and light orange. The minimum possible number of changes is one; in this case, color changes only once on the tree and is a defining characteristic of <button class='glossary-text'>taxa</button> D and E. A shared <button class='glossary-text'>derived</button> characteristic that defines a <button class='glossary-text'>clade</button> from others on the tree is called a <button class='glossary-text'>synapomorphy</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A cladogram showing potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A cladogram showing potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree

pageData.text: If there is sufficient knowledge about the taxa to assume that some characteristics are sequential, for instance, if five sides are dependent on first having four sides, then the addition of the side between taxa A and B can also be considered to be a synapomorphy. In the absence of explicit knowledge of the characters, it is best not to assume any such relationships.

In this data matrix, the number of angles could have been included as an additional <button class='glossary-text'>character</button>. However, in geometry, the number of sides and the number of angles are always related. If the number of angles were to be included, the trees would be unnecessarily weighted in favor of those that minimized the number of changes in these linked traits. Phylogeneticists are frequently unaware of all these potential relationships. The use of many traits helps to minimize the impact of linked characters.

The is used to compare trees generated using the same data set. It is a simple ratio of the minimum changes in characters to the actual changes on a particular tree. The closer the index is to one, the better, or more parsimonious, the tree is. is the principle that the simplest solution is the most likely.

Figures 4 and <button class='resource-text'>5</button> have the same basic structure as <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>, but the <button class='glossary-text'>taxa</button> have been moved around. In the case of Figure 4, the number of character changes that would have been required for this tree to be true would have been eight (compared with seven in Figure 3). The ancestor of taxa E, D, and C would have had to change color from blue to orange. Taxon C would then have had to revert to blue. Such reversions are not without precedence in the real evolutionary tree.
Fish and snakes have no legs; however, morphological evidence (the presence of vestigial legs in snake skeletons) shows that the ancestors of snakes had legs.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A cladogram showing different potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A cladogram showing different potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree

pageData.desc: Figure 5: A third cladogram showing potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A third cladogram showing potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree

pageData.text: Figure 5 has the same length and <button class='glossary-text'>consistency index</button> as <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>. It is possible to have two trees with the same consistency index. If these trees are the shortest, then both trees remain hypotheses of the evolutionary relationships.

It is possible that more <button class='glossary-text'>taxa</button> or more characteristics will help to resolve the results. In this case, however, there is at least one shorter tree (Figure 6). The topology of this tree is more complex than that of the previous trees. E and D form a sub-group, as do C and B. The only <button class='glossary-text'>character</button> that would have had to arise twice independently is “outline.”

pageData.desc: Figure 6: A fourth cladogram showing potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree
pageData.altText: Figure 6: A fourth cladogram showing potential relationships between the five figures of the example; character state changes are mapped on the tree

pageData.text: Figure 7 shows synapomorphies mapped onto a real <button class='glossary-text'>cladogram</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: A cladogram depicting the evolutionary relationships between a lancelet, shark, perch, sparrow, and mouse;  key characteristics are mapped on the cladogram
pageData.altText: Figure 7: A cladogram depicting the evolutionary relationships between a lancelet, shark, perch, sparrow, and mouse;  key characteristics are mapped on the cladogram

pageData.text: Using DNA or protein sequences in phylogenetic analyses is very similar to using morphological <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button>. One major difference is in determining characters and <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button>.
DNA sequences are run through a computer algorithm designed to align similar sequences. There are several different algorithms available. One of the most common is the CLUSTAL algorithm.

Figure 8 shows an alignment with 25 <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button>, each with five possible <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button>: adenine, cytosine, guanine, thymine, and absent. Molecular characters are treated in exactly the same way as physical characters. In this case, only six sites have differences among the sequences (Figure 9). These differences are called <button class='glossary-text'>informative characters</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Hypothetical DNA sequence alignment

pageData.desc: Figure 9: The DNA sequence alignment from Figure 4 reduced to its informative characters
pageData.altText: Figure 9: The DNA sequence alignment from Figure 4 reduced to its informative characters

pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>character</button> matrix like Table 2, is created and the characters are assigned a <button class='glossary-text'>character state</button> value. In this example, where the “A” sequence is considered the <button class='glossary-text'>outgroup</button>, the value of character of A at a site is given a value of 0. In the same way as for physical characters, molecular characters can be used to determine whether a tree is the most parsimonious one.

pageData.question: What of the following statements best describes parsimony?

options.text: The simplest solution is the most likely solution.
A phylogenetic tree with the most changes is the more likely hypothesis.
The best phylogenetic trees lack outgroups.
The most consistent data form the most accurate phylogenies.
The fewer the number of synapomorphies, the more accurate the data.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The principle of parsimony states that the best tree is the one with the fewest number of changes; the simplest solution is the most likely.

pageData.question: Which of the following numbers is used to describe the character states of an outgroup?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: By definition, the character state of the outgroup is zero.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cladistic methods evaluate phylogenetic trees based on the principle of parsimony. This type of analysis requires an outgroup, i.e., a taxon that is known to be outside or ancestral to the group of taxa being examined (taxon A in Table 2). Taxa are grouped according to their changes from the outgroup. Ideally, all possible tree arrangements are tested; however, historically, this has been very difficult. A simple tree, containing only five organisms and having the simplest construction with only four internal nodes, would have 105 possible trees. In the same way as for physical characters, molecular characters can be used to determine whether a tree is the most parsimonious one.

hintData.body: Cladistic methods evaluate phylogenetic trees based on the principle of parsimony. This type of analysis requires an outgroup, i.e., a taxon that is known to be outside or ancestral to the group of taxa being examined (taxon A in Table 2). Taxa are grouped according to their changes from the outgroup. Ideally, all possible tree arrangements are tested; however, historically, this has been very difficult. A simple tree, containing only five organisms and having the simplest construction with only four internal nodes, would have 105 possible trees. In the same way as for physical characters, molecular characters can be used to determine whether a tree is the most parsimonious one.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. First, you will compile a list of character states for the shells. Then, you will define the out group. Next, you will assign numbers to each character state. Then, you will use the numbers to map each set of character states on to the cladograms provided. Finally, you will calculate the consistency index for each cladogram.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for the Cladistics investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, item 580209.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from laboratory materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the characters used in cladistics?

options.text: structures derived from a common ancestor
structural similarities due to similar habitats
structures and behaviors from a predetermined list

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is an example of a character state?
Which term is used for a group of related organisms and their common ancestor?
What is represented by a node in a cladogram?

options.text: the most recent common ancestor of the related taxa
the most unusual character shared by related taxa
the most distant common ancestor of related taxa
the most distinctive character shared by unrelated taxa
the occurrence of a polyphyletic group

assestmentData.question: Which of the following results from inadvertently grouping organisms based on analogous structure?
In cladistic methodology, the simplest – and therefore most likely – solution is best described as which of the following?

Which of the following characteristics of these taxa is a derived character?
😶😑😐
A   B   C
Which of the following parts of the cladogram is a synapomorphy?

imageData.desc: A cladogram with a long line extending up and to the left and two smaller lines branching from the line up and to the right. The top end point of left-most line is labeled 1. The intersection between the left-most line and the branch closest to number 1 is labeled 2. The intersection between the left-most line and the branch furthest from number 1 is labeled 3. A short horizontal line intersecting the left-most line near its bottom end point is labeled 4. A second short horizontal line intersecting the branch furthest from number 1 is labeled 5.
imageData.altText: A cladogram with a long line extending up and to the left and two smaller lines branching from the line up and to the right. The top end point of left-most line is labeled 1. The intersection between the left-most line and the branch closest to number 1 is labeled 2. The intersection between the left-most line and the branch furthest from number 1 is labeled 3. A short horizontal line intersecting the left-most line near its bottom end point is labeled 4. A second short horizontal line intersecting the branch furthest from number 1 is labeled 5.

In Activity 1, you will examine the characteristics of shells to identify <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button> changes, map the character state changes onto two possible <button class='glossary-text'>cladograms</button>, and calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>consistency index</button> of each.
Examine each of the shells in your kit.

Using the shells and the descriptions in Tables 3A and 3B, compile a list of potential <button class='glossary-text'>characters</button> and define <button class='glossary-text'>character states</button> for each character. Choose an <button class='glossary-text'>outgroup</button> and assign the character states numbers based on assigning 0 as the character state number possessed by the outgroup.

pageData.text: Fill in Data Table 1 with character states for each sample.

Below are two , which are also shown on the cladogram template. The first is generated from a distance matrix using the COI mitochondrial gene; the second is generated from the 16S ribosomal subunit mitochondrial gene. Map the character state changes from Data Table 1 onto each tree in the template, or draw each tree on your own sheet of paper before mapping the changes and calculate the .

pageData.desc: Figure 10: Phylogenetic tree based on the COI locus
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Phylogenetic tree based on the COI locus

pageData.desc: Figure 11: Phylogenetic tree based on the 16S locus
pageData.altText: Figure 11: Phylogenetic tree based on the 16S locus

pageData.text: COI or cytochrome oxidase I and 16S ribosomal subunit genes are found in mitochondrial DNA. COI codes for a protein involved in the mitochondrial electron transport chain. The 16S ribosomal subunit gene codes for structural RNA used to create part of the mitochondrial ribosomes. Understanding the precise functions of these genes is not necessary when using them in phylogenetic analysis. Both genes are frequently used because they are found in almost all organisms, have critical functions, and do not accumulate changes very quickly; hence, they are ideal candidate genes for examining groups of distantly related organisms.

data.title: Ancestral
data.content: Describes a character trait that is shared with an outgroup

data.title: Clade
data.content: A monophyletic group composed of a common ancestor and all its descendents

data.title: Cladistic methods
data.content: a method of constructing phylogenic trees based on the principle of parsimony

data.title: Cladogram
data.content: A graphical depiction of a clade

data.title: Consistency index
data.content: A ratio of the minimum changes in characters to the actual changes on a particular tree;  the closer to 1, the more parsimonous the tree is

data.title: Derived
data.content: Describes a character trait that is different from the outgroup

data.title: Genome
data.content: The complete set of DNA in an organism

data.title: Informative character
data.content: A difference between some but not all members of a group that allows for relationship inferencing between the members

data.title: Outgroup
data.content: A taxon that is known to be outside the group of taxa being examined

data.title: Paraphyletic group
data.content: A group that contains its common ancestor, but excludes one ore more descendent groups

data.title: Parsimony (parsimonious)
data.content: The principle that states the simplest solution is the most likely

data.title: Phenetic methods
data.content: A method of constructing phylogenic trees using distance calculations based on the number of differences between pairs of taxa

data.title: Phylogeny
data.content: A prediction of an evolutionary relationship

data.title: Polyphyletic group
data.content: A taxonomic group that consists of species of mixed evolutionary origin; usually the result of creating a phylogeny based on analogous structures

data.title: Synapomorphy
data.content: A shared derived characteristic that defines a clade from others on the tree

data.title: Taxonomy
data.content: A system of naming and classifying organisms
